headline: Tesla: What the end of the EV tax credit means for automakers
summary: Tesla (TSLA) reported record third quarter EV deliveries — 497,099 (vs. expectations of 439,612) — on Thursday as the electric vehicle tax credit expired on September 30. Additionally, US automakers Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) saw notable gains in their own vehicle sales, propped up by EVs. Kelley Blue Book executive editor Brian Moody speaks with Allie Canal about what these sales figures signal for the EV market and Tesla heading into the fourth quarter. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: GM exec. discusses tariffs, strong Q3 sales, and EV tax credit
summary: General Motors (GM) reported strong third quarter sales. GM's Buick and GMC global vice president, Jaclyn McQuaid, sits down with Yahoo Finance Senior Reporters Allie Canal and Pras Subramanian to discuss tariff impacts, sales trends, the China market, the expiration of the electric vehicle (EV) tax credit, and more. Check out Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi's interview with Ford (F) CEO Jim Farley. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: South Africa secures China, India investments to boost local auto manufacturing
summary: GQEBERHA South Africa (Reuters) -South Africa has secured commitments from Chinese and Indian car companies to upgrade their semi-knocked-down (SKD) vehicle assembly operations to full-scale manufacturing, the South African trade minister said on Thursday, as industry leaders call for more domestic production.  The government is in talks with multinational carmakers, who have South African factories - including Toyota and Ford and their suppliers - on ways to safeguard the industry's future as it navigates declining production volumes, stiff competition from China, tariff uncertainty and an expensive shift to electric vehicles.  Auto leaders warned on Wednesday at an annual auto conference that if South Africa does not protect its industry from imports, it risks driving de-industrialization in the country.

raw.headline: South Africa secures China, India investments to boost local auto manufacturing

The government is in talks with multinational carmakers, who have South African factories - including Toyota and Ford and their suppliers - on ways to safeguard the industry's future as it navigates declining production volumes, stiff competition from China, tariff uncertainty and an expensive shift to electric vehicles.  Auto leaders warned on Wednesday at an annual auto conference that if South Africa does not protect its industry from imports, it risks driving de-industrialization in the country.

headline: Ford (F): Valuation in Focus After Record EV Sales and Tax Credit Expiry Shake Up Industry Outlook
summary: Ford Motor (NYSE:F) just reported a record spike in U.S. electric vehicle sales for the third quarter. However, investors are closely watching what comes next as the $7,500 federal EV tax credit has expired. CEO Jim Farley’s warning that the loss of this incentive could shrink the U.S. EV market by half sets a new backdrop for the company’s growth story. See our latest analysis for Ford Motor. After trending upward on the heels of record EV sales, Ford’s share price has settled at $12.27...

headline: NFL Legacy Twins, Former UVA D1 Athletes, Launch Staxx™ App to Power Financial Health and Wealth Building for Under-30 Earners in the Era of NIL and the Athlete-Class
summary: Hailey and Myla Barnett announce the launch of their new app and financial services digital platform, Staxx™ App, that brings financial empowerment, organization and education to thousands involved in youth sports and under 30 earners. Their mission is to reach thousands, helping users build stronger financial foundations and navigate the often-complex world of youth athletics.

headline: Great Cons Are Part of the American Story. And That Might Not Be So Bad.
summary: When Theranos founder  Elizabeth Holmes  was on trial for misrepresenting the startup’s finances and business prospects, several people tried to put the practice of hyping supposed tech breakthroughs in context.  “It’s common in Silicon Valley for promoters to engage in that type of conduct,” said U.S. District Judge Edward Davila.  “This verdict makes me concerned that the spirit of entrepreneurship in America is in jeopardy,” he wrote.
